channel.title: NPR Topics: Science
channel.description: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: NASA chief blasts Boeing, space agency for failed Starliner astronaut mission
item.description: NASA's Jared Isaacman slammed Boeing for failures with its Starliner spacecraft, which was deemed unsafe to return its crew of two astronauts from the International Space Station
item.content:encoded:
NASA's Jared Isaacman slammed Boeing for failures with its Starliner spacecraft, which was deemed unsafe to return its crew of two astronauts from the International Space Station

(Image credit: NASA)
item.dc:creator: Brendan Byrne

item.title: Scientists analyzed bottle residue from ancient Rome. They found human feces
item.description: Archeologists found evidence that ancient Romans may have used a medical treatment involving perfume... and human feces.
item.content:encoded: Archeologists found evidence that ancient Romans may have used a medical treatment involving perfume... and human feces.
item.dc:creator: Ari Daniel

item.title: This week in science: Mental health and chatbots, ultrarunning and intermittent fasting
item.description: NPR's science podcast Short Wave talk about how ultrarunning affects the body, the trend of intermittent fasting and how to protect people's mental health when they talk with chatbots.
item.content:encoded: NPR's science podcast Short Wave talk about how ultrarunning affects the body, the trend of intermittent fasting and how to protect people's mental health when they talk with chatbots.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Carlson

item.title: Baby chicks link certain sounds with shapes, just like humans do
item.description: A surprising new study shows that baby chickens react the same way that humans do when tested for something called the "bouba-kiki effect," which has been linked to the emergence of language.
item.content:encoded:
A surprising new study shows that baby chickens react the same way that humans do when tested for something called the "bouba-kiki effect," which has been linked to the emergence of language.

(Image credit: Elena Goncharova)
item.dc:creator: Nell Greenfieldboyce

item.title: That ain't perfume! Ancient bottle contained feces, likely used for medicine
item.description: Researchers found a tiny bottle from ancient Rome that contained fecal residue and traces of aromatics, offering evidence that poop was used medicinally more than 2,000 years ago.
item.content:encoded:
Researchers found a tiny bottle from ancient Rome that contained fecal residue and traces of aromatics, offering evidence that poop was used medicinally more than 2,000 years ago.

(Image credit: Ilker Demirbolat (left); Cenker Atila (right))
item.dc:creator: Ari Daniel

item.title: Mass grave sheds light on 7th century plague
item.description: In modern-day Jordan, a 1500-year old mass grave sheds light on the lives of people affected by the Plague of Justinian.
item.content:encoded: In modern-day Jordan, a 1500-year old mass grave sheds light on the lives of people affected by the Plague of Justinian.
item.dc:creator: Durrie Bouscaren

item.title: This form of mental exercise may cut dementia risk for decades
item.description: A study finds that people who did one specific form of brain training in the 1990s were less likely to be diagnosed with dementia over the next 20 years.
item.content:encoded:
A study finds that people who did one specific form of brain training in the 1990s were less likely to be diagnosed with dementia over the next 20 years.

(Image credit: spawns)
item.dc:creator: Jon Hamilton

item.title: Surprise shark caught on camera for first time in Antarctica's near-freezing deep
item.description: Many experts had thought sharks didn't exist in the frigid waters of Antarctica.
item.content:encoded:
Many experts had thought sharks didn't exist in the frigid waters of Antarctica.

(Image credit: University of Western Australia)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: AI is helping individual scientists, study suggests â€” but not science
item.description: Artificial intelligence is helping researchers advance their careers and drill deeper into specific questions, but it is not necessarily benefiting science on the whole.
item.content:encoded: Artificial intelligence is helping researchers advance their careers and drill deeper into specific questions, but it is not necessarily benefiting science on the whole.
item.dc:creator: Katia Riddle

item.title: Why do humans kiss?
item.description: Matilda Brindle, an evolutionary biologist at the University of Oxford, explains.
item.content:encoded: Matilda Brindle, an evolutionary biologist at the University of Oxford, explains.
item.dc:creator: Emily Kwong
